title: MA Personal Lines Insurance Law Practice Exam 1
description: Practice exam 1, specifically targeting weak performance areas: General Insurance, Property & Casualty Basics, Insurance Regulation, and Other Coverages.

questions.question: Which type of risk involves the possibility of loss only, with no opportunity for gain, and is generally the only type of risk that is insurable?
questions.explanation: Pure risk provides only for the possibility of a loss. Property and casualty insurance protects against pure risk only. Speculative risk involves an opportunity for gain that could result in loss (e.g., gambling) and cannot be insured.
questions.distractor_logic: Speculative risk involves gain or loss. Fundamental and Dynamic risks are not the primary terms used to define insurability in the provided text.

questions.question: Which section of an insurance policy personalizes the contract by identifying the named insured, the address of the property, the coverage limits, and the premium amount?
questions.explanation: The declarations page 'personalizes' the policy and provides an assortment of information regarding the property or exposures being insured, including the name/address of the insured, coverage limits, and premium.
questions.distractor_logic: The Insuring Agreement describes the promise to pay. Conditions identify responsibilities. Exclusions identify what is not covered.

questions.question: Under Massachusetts law, a producer who pays a commission or fee to an unlicensed person for selling insurance is subject to a fine of:

options.A: Not less than $10 nor more than $100
options.B: Not less than $50 nor more than $500
options.C: Not less than $100 nor more than $1,000
options.D: Not less than $500 nor more than $5,000

questions.explanation: An insurer or producer shall not pay a commission... to a person for selling insurance unless such person is duly licensed. Anyone violating this regulation may be fined not less than $50 nor more than $500.
questions.distractor_logic: $10-$100 is for Impersonation. $100-$1,000 is for Perjury. $500-$5,000 is for operating an auto without insurance.

questions.question: A dishonest character of an insured, such as someone who intentionally damages their own property to file a claim, is classified as what type of hazard?
questions.explanation: Moral hazard may heighten the chance of a loss due to the dishonest character of an insured. An insured who intentionally damages his or her own property... is an illustration of this type of hazard.
questions.distractor_logic: Physical hazards are tangible conditions (e.g., gasoline storage). Morale hazards involve carelessness or indifference (e.g., leaving keys in car).

questions.question: Under the Massachusetts Personal Auto Policy, Part 8 (Limited Collision) will pay for direct and accidental damage to the covered auto ONLY if:

options.A: The insured is more than 50% at fault
options.B: The insured is not more than 50% at fault and can identify the responsible driver
options.C: The damage is caused by a hit-and-run driver

questions.explanation: Part 8 covers direct and accidental damage to the covered auto if the insured is not more than 50% at-fault and he or she can identify the responsible driver.
questions.distractor_logic: A is incorrect because the insured must be *not more than* 50% at fault. C is incorrect because the driver must be identified. D is incorrect as Comprehensive is a separate part (Part 9).

questions.question: Which legal defense against negligence asserts that an intervening cause interrupted the chain of events, thereby relieving the defendant of liability?
questions.explanation: Under the Intervening Cause defense, a defendant possesses no liability if an injury to a third party is caused by a separate unrelated cause which interrupts a series chain of events.
questions.distractor_logic: Comparative negligence apportions fault based on degree. Last clear chance applies if the injured party could have avoided the loss. Assumption of risk applies when danger is voluntarily accepted.

questions.question: When an insurer pays a property claim in Massachusetts, within how many days must they pay the claim after receiving the written proof of loss?
questions.explanation: Massachusetts regulations state that once an insurer receives a written proof of loss from an insured, it must pay the claim, if legitimate, within thirty (30) days.
questions.distractor_logic: 15 days applies to the notice of decision to repair/replace. 60 days is the timeframe for an insured to demand appraisers if there is a dispute.

questions.question: Which method of handling risk involves a group of people agreeing to assume a specific portion of a loss, such as a partnership?
questions.explanation: Sharing involves risk distributed among an assortment of persons. Each party agrees to assume a specific portion of the loss.
questions.distractor_logic: Retention is assuming the risk oneself. Reduction is minimizing severity. Avoidance is eliminating the activity entirely.

questions.question: A 'Binder' provides temporary coverage while the actual policy is being produced. What is the typical maximum duration for a binder in Massachusetts fire/property insurance?
questions.explanation: A binder provides temporary insurance and is usually not good for more than 30 days... Massachusetts fire regulations specifically mention binders may be extended for up to 30 days.
questions.distractor_logic: 60 days is listed as a possibility in general text, but 30 days is the specific MA fire regulation limit mentioned.

questions.question: Which entity establishes the Safe Driver Insurance Plan (SDIP) in Massachusetts to modify premium rates based on driving records?
questions.explanation: The Safe Driver Insurance Plan was established by CAR (Commonwealth Auto Reinsurers) to modify premium rates based on accident frequency, moving violations, etc..
questions.distractor_logic: The Division of Insurance regulates. The RMV handles licensing. The AG prosecutes illegal activity.

questions.question: Which type of insurer is owned by its policyholders and issues participating policies that may pay dividends?
questions.explanation: A mutual insurer is an insurance company without capital stock that is owned by its policyholders. Mutual insurers issue participating policies.
questions.distractor_logic: Stock companies are owned by stockholders. Risk Retention Groups are group-owned liability insurers for specific businesses.

questions.question: Under the Massachusetts Personal Auto Policy, Optional Part 5 (Optional Bodily Injury to Others) includes coverage for bail bonds up to what amount?
questions.explanation: Part 5 also includes coverage for bail bonds up to $250 if the insured or a family member is arrested as a result of an auto accident.
questions.distractor_logic: $500 is the Fire Dept charge limit in HO policies. $1,000 is the limit for non-installed electronics in auto policies.

questions.question: What is the primary difference between a 'Direct Loss' and an 'Indirect Loss'?

options.A: Direct loss is physical damage; Indirect loss is the consequential financial loss resulting from the physical damage.
options.B: Direct loss covers buildings; Indirect loss covers contents.
options.C: Direct loss is paid at Replacement Cost; Indirect loss is paid at ACV.
options.D: Direct loss implies negligence; Indirect loss implies strict liability.

questions.explanation: A direct loss involves direct physical loss to tangible property... An indirect loss is an additional form of loss that results from a direct physical loss (e.g., loss of use, loss of income).
questions.distractor_logic: B, C, and D are incorrect definitions. Coverage type and valuation method do not define direct vs. indirect.

questions.question: If an insurer in Massachusetts wishes to non-renew a Homeowners policy, how many days' written notice must be provided to the insured?
questions.explanation: The Massachusetts Amendatory Endorsement (HO-01-20) specifies that an insured must be provided with 45 days written notice of non-renewal.
questions.distractor_logic: 20 days is for cancellation to the mortgagee. 10 days is for non-payment of premium.

questions.question: When a personal property item is 'Scheduled' on a Homeowners policy (e.g., via the Scheduled Personal Property Endorsement), which of the following is TRUE?

options.A: It is subject to the standard policy deductible.
options.B: It is covered against broad form perils only.
options.C: It is covered against mysterious disappearance and has no deductible.
options.D: Coverage is limited to the residence premises.

questions.explanation: Once property is scheduled individually it is: (1) taken out of the Coverage C limit... (3) covered against mysterious disappearance: and (4) not affected by a deductible.
questions.distractor_logic: A is false (no deductible). B is false (open peril/mysterious disappearance). D is false (worldwide coverage).

questions.question: Under the Law of Agency, the 'Principal' refers to which party?
questions.explanation: The insurer is referred to as the principal. The principal is the entity that the agent/producer represents with regard to agreements with third parties.
questions.distractor_logic: The producer is the agent. The applicant is the third party.

questions.question: Which of the following acts is considered 'Coercion' under Massachusetts unfair trade practice laws?

options.A: Comparing policies to induce a lapse
options.B: A lender requiring a borrower to purchase insurance from a specific agency to get a loan
options.D: Making false statements about a competitor

questions.explanation: A lender may not inform a borrower that in order to receive a loan he or she must purchase property or casualty insurance from a specific insurer or agency. This is coercion or intimidation.
questions.distractor_logic: A is Twisting. C is Misrepresentation. D is Defamation.

questions.question: Which type of loss valuation pays the cost to repair or replace damaged property without deduction for depreciation?
questions.explanation: Replacement Cost is the amount needed today to replace damaged or destroyed property... paying for new materials... without a deduction for depreciation.
questions.distractor_logic: ACV is replacement cost minus depreciation. Market value is based on the price property would sell for.

questions.question: The Massachusetts Insurance Commissioner has the power to do all of the following EXCEPT:

options.A: Issue Certificates of Authority to insurers
options.B: Approve policy forms and premium rates

questions.explanation: The Commissioner refers information regarding licensees who break the law to the Attorney General... for prosecution. The Attorney General will then prosecute licensees. The Commissioner acts regarding regulatory issues.
questions.distractor_logic: A, B, and D are explicit powers of the Commissioner listed in the text.

questions.question: Under Part 9 (Comprehensive) of the MA Auto Policy, what specific optional deductible is available for glass damage?
questions.explanation: The policy states regarding Part 9: 'Also, a $100 glass damage deductible is optional'.
questions.distractor_logic: $0, $50, and $250 are not the specific optional glass deductible cited in the text.

questions.question: In a liability claim, 'Vicarious Liability' refers to:

options.C: Liability for the actions of another person

questions.explanation: Vicarious liability exists because of the negligence of a person engaged by an insured (e.g., employee or child). The insured is found liable for negligent acts by that individual.
questions.distractor_logic: A is Strict Liability. B is Contractual Liability.

questions.question: According to continuing education requirements, how many credit hours in 'ethics' must a Massachusetts producer complete during each renewal cycle?
questions.explanation: Licensees must complete three (3) credit hours of continuing education in ethics. These three credits are part of the requirement.
questions.distractor_logic: A, B, and D are incorrect. 3 credits is the specific requirement stated in the text.

questions.question: How is 'Flood' defined in a standard flood policy regarding the area affected?

options.A: It must affect at least 50% of the insured's property.
options.B: It must be a general condition affecting two or more acres of normally dry land or two or more properties.
options.C: It must result from a hurricane or tidal wave.
options.D: It must last for at least 24 hours.

questions.explanation: A covered flood must be a general condition of the area... two or more properties or two or more acres of land must be affected.
questions.distractor_logic: A, C, and D are not part of the standard NFIP definition of flood provided in the text.

questions.question: Which of the following describes 'Reinsurance'?

options.A: Insurance purchased by an individual to cover high value items.
options.B: Insurance purchased by an insurer to transfer risk to another insurer.
options.C: Insurance provided by the state for high-risk drivers.

questions.explanation: Reinsurance is actually insurance from insurers... The transfer of risk from one insurance company to another.
questions.distractor_logic: A is typically a Personal Articles Floater. C is the Residual Market/Assigned Risk. D is uninsurable.

questions.question: Once a Massachusetts auto policy has been in effect for 90 days, the insurer may cancel it for all of the following reasons EXCEPT:

options.C: Failure to pay surcharges for moving violations

questions.explanation: Once a policy has been in effect for 90 days, an insurer may only cancel for: nonpayment, license/registration suspension, failure to pay surcharges, or fraud.
questions.distractor_logic: Accident frequency (e.g., four or more at-fault) is a reason for cancelling *Collision* coverage or non-renewal, but 'Involvement in two at-fault accidents' is not a listed valid reason for cancelling the entire policy after 90 days.
